data.text: Is Refilling a Propane Cartridge Good or Bad?
Greetings from Peshawar Pakistan. Refilling your propane cartridge?????? Good? Bad??? Your thoughts on this matter, why one should do it or not do it? Any tips or suggestions welcome.

Well, it’s hard to buy the gas that goes in those, it’s usually a proprietary mix off propane and butane. But you can just refill them with straight propane. Oil the valve so and it will help prevent leaking but 20% of them will leak anyway once you refill them. So don’t store them indoors or take them on long trips (or they may be empty by the time you use them)
data.author: Zack Martinez

data.text: Just check the proper weight of gas that you fill in. Do not overfill. I fill my cartridges for many years ...
data.author: Hynek Cvalín

data.text: Are you sure for 100% propane ? I thought it had way too much pressure to contain only propane.
data.author: Augustin De Bie

data.text: Well I fill them with P/B mixture from 10 kg cartridge used for cooking. Using kitchen scales to fill the correct amount. No problem ever.
data.author: Hynek Cvalín

data.text: Oh sorry I answered to the wrong comment :D
data.author: Augustin De Bie

data.text: I refill my small ones with gas from larger versions. Need a two sided valve and put the canister to be filled in the deep freeze first. Weigh the canister during filling so you do not overfill. Some YouTube videos on it. Good luck!
data.author: Hugh Robinson

data.text: No problem if done safely
data.author: Ashley Burton

data.text: Yes, gas is pretty expensive now but a heck of a lot cheaper when bought in larger canisters. Buy a two-way valve and refill the smaller canister from the larger one. Weigh the smaller one when new to avoid overfilling in the future.
data.author: Jon Mathias

data.text: Did not even think this was possible. Who is willing to share details on the two way valve one would need for this? Where can this be bought. Refilling the smaller ones we bring on our trips is more durable than buying new ones all the time. Not knowing how much gas is still in the ones used is a thing as well.
data.author: Machiel Appel

data.text: Weigh it when full then track the weight until empty. Write the weights on the side to track usage and weight and then you'll have an idea of how much use you can get out of it from its weight.
data.author: Matthew Leo

data.text: There is a lovely adapter on Ali that allow you to connect these small ones to a 10 kg canister.
data.author: Hynek Cvalín

data.text: can you share a link, can't find it, don't know what search terms to use. Thanks.

data.author: Hynek Cvalín

data.text: If you use a lot of it, maybe, but i hardly see the risk/benefits value to refill a $5 can, they were not designed to be refilled.
data.author: Guillaume Dougados

data.text: Well at least you know your limits, this is an easy and safe job, the smaller canisters are not easy to come by in a lot of areas, and they sell out due to peoples preference, and no one wants to lug around the large ones, not designed to be refilled?? Don't believe everything...
data.author: Patrick Gormley

data.text: They're designed to be screwed on and off stoves many times. You're only adding one cycle each time by refilling it. It's both financially and environmentally beneficial.
data.author: Jon Mathias

data.text: Most of these small canisters are for iso butane or butane or a proprietary mix with that & propane. Straight propane needs a canister that’s meant to hold higher pressure. Certainly you can refill canisters using the same mix they were designed for, but refilling with a different mix of gas could yield dangerous results (propane has 4x the vapour pressure of butane). I bought a 2 way valve on Amazon, but haven’t used it yet. My intention is to empty a few half or quarter empty canisters into one canister, so that I don’t keep accumulating canisters that aren’t full enough to take on a trip.
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: Who said it was being refilled with a different mix?, its being refilled from a larger can using the same mix..
data.author: Patrick Gormley

data.text: if you read earlier comments, some were suggesting they refilled from a propane canister
